choices.text: Eustachian tube
Mastoid air cells
Aditus to mastoid antrum
Internal auditory canal

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not a part of the middle ear cleft?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Internal auditory canal

 

The middle ear cleft is an anatomically connected air-filled system that includes:

 

  • Eustachian tube – connects the nasopharynx to the middle ear and helps in pressure equalization.
  • Middle ear cavity (tympanum) – houses the ossicles.
  • Aditus to mastoid antrum – a communication channel between the epitympanum and mastoid antrum.
  • Mastoid antrum and air cells – air-filled spaces within the mastoid bone, connected via the aditus.

 

These structures form a continuous pathway for air and potential infections (e.g., from acute otitis media to mastoiditis).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option D. Internal auditory canal: 

 

  • This canal lies within the petrous part of the temporal bone and transmits the facial and vestibulocochlear nerves.
  • It is not air-filled and is not part of the middle ear cleft.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The middle ear cleft includes the Eustachian tube, middle ear cavity, aditus, mastoid antrum, and mastoid air cells.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 5

choices.text: It is formed by the round window
Scutum is located on the medial wall of the middle ear
Tympanic membrane forms the lateral wall of the middle ear
Scutum is part of the posterior wall of the middle ear

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the lateral wall of the middle ear is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tympanic membrane forms the lateral wall of the middle ear

 

The lateral wall of the middle ear is primarily formed by the tympanic membrane, which separates the external auditory canal (outer ear) from the middle ear cavity. Hence, it also represents the medial wall of the external ear.

 

Additionally, the scutum is a small bony plate forming the superior part of the lateral wall of the epitympanum (attic). It is a key landmark in cholesteatoma, which often erodes it.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is formed by the round window: The round window lies on the medial wall of the middle ear cavity, just below the oval window.

 

Option B. Scutum is located on the medial wall of the middle ear: The scutum is part of the lateral bony wall, above the tympanic membrane (attic region).

 

Option D. Scutum is part of the posterior wall of the middle ear: The scutum is located anterior-lateral, in the attic region (lateral wall of epitympanum), not posterior.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral wall of the middle ear is formed by the tympanic membrane and the scutum, which is often eroded in cholesteatoma.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 5

choices.text: It is used to identify the facial recess, which lies 1.5 cm deep to it
It is bounded by the posterosuperior meatal wall, zygomatic arch, and sigmoid sinus
It helps identify the mastoid antrum, which lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to it
It is bordered superiorly by the parietal eminence and anteriorly by the Eustachian tube

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes MacEwen’s triangle, a key surgical landmark in mastoid surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It helps identify the mastoid antrum, which lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to it

 

MacEwen’s triangle is a key surgical surface landmark used during mastoidectomy to locate the mastoid antrum, especially in pediatric cases where landmarks can be variable.

 

  • The mastoid antrum lies about 1.5 cm deep to MacEwen’s triangle, making it an essential guide in mastoid surgeries.
  • This triangle is located behind the external auditory canal and guides safe entry during cortical mastoidectomy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is used to identify the facial recess, which lies 1.5 cm deep to it: Incorrect

 

  • The facial recess lies within the middle ear, not related to MacEwen’s triangle.
  • The facial recess is identified between the facial nerve and chorda tympani, not through surface landmarks.

 

Option B. It is bounded by the posterosuperior meatal wall, zygomatic arch, and sigmoid sinus:  Incorrect

 

  • The actual boundaries of MacEwen’s triangle are:
    • Anteriorly: Posterosuperior meatal wall
    • Superiorly: Temporal line
    • Posteriorly: A vertical tangent to the posterior canal wall
  • The zygomatic arch and sigmoid sinus are unrelated to its boundaries.

 

Option D. It is bordered superiorly by the parietal eminence and anteriorly by the Eustachian tube: Incorrect

 

  • These landmarks are not related to the triangle.
  • The temporal line, not the parietal eminence, forms the superior boundary, and the Eustachian tube is not part of the surface triangle anatomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MacEwen’s triangle is a surface landmark bounded by the posterosuperior meatal wall, temporal line, and a posterior tangent to the external canal, used to identify the mastoid antrum located approximately 1.5 cm deep to it.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 5,6

choices.text: By fibrous bands at two points of contact
By the annular ligament circumferentially along its periphery
Through a direct bony fusion with the vestibule
By a fluid seal formed by the round window membrane

questions.text: How is the stapes footplate attached to the oval window of the cochlea?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) By the annular ligament circumferentially along its periphery

 

The stapes is the third and innermost ossicle in the middle ear, and its footplate plays a critical role in transmitting sound vibrations into the inner ear:

 

  • The footplate of the stapes fits into the oval window (fenestra vestibuli) of the medial wall of the middle ear.
  • It is held in place by the annular ligament, which attaches around the entire periphery of the footplate in a circumferential manner.
  • This allows the footplate to vibrate and transmit mechanical energy to the perilymph of the scala vestibuli in the cochlea.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. By fibrous bands at two points of contact: Incorrect

 

  • There are no two-point fibrous attachments; the connection is circular and uniform, not focal.

 

Option C. Through a direct bony fusion with the vestibule: Incorrect

 

  • A bony fusion at this site would impede movement, as occurs in otosclerosis.
  • Under normal conditions, the stapes is not fused, but freely mobile, thanks to the annular ligament.

 

Option D. By a fluid seal formed by the round window membrane: Incorrect

 

  • The round window is located below the oval window, and is unrelated to stapes attachment.
  • It acts as a pressure-release valve during cochlear fluid movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stapes footplate is attached to the oval window via the annular ligament in a circumferential manner, allowing sound transmission to the inner ear.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 86

choices.text: Chorda tympani
Auriculotemporal nerve
Greater auricular nerve
Nerve to mylohyoid

questions.text: A patient develops sweating and flushing over the cheek while eating, following parotid gland surgery. Frey’s syndrome is suspected. Which of the following nerves is involved in the aberrant reinnervation responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auriculotemporal nerve

 

  • Final carrier of secretomotor fibres to parotid; responsible for Frey’s syndrome when misdirected.

 

Frey’s syndrome (gustatory sweating) occurs due to:

 

  • Aberrant regeneration of auriculotemporal nerve fibres after parotid gland surgery or trauma.
  • Parasympathetic secretomotor fibres (originally destined for the parotid gland) regenerate incorrectly and innervate sweat glands of the overlying skin.
  • As a result, sweating and flushing occur over the parotid region while eating (gustatory stimulus).

 

The auriculotemporal nerve:

 

  • Is a branch of mandibular nerve (V3)
  • Carries postganglionic parasympathetic fibres from the otic ganglion to the parotid gland
  • Final step of the tympanic plexus → lesser petrosal → otic ganglion → auriculotemporal → parotid pathway

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chorda tympani: Carries secretomotor fibres to submandibular and sublingual glands, not parotid.

 

Option C. Greater auricular nerve: Supplies cutaneous sensation over parotid region but is not involved in salivation.

 

Option D. Nerve to mylohyoid: Motor branch to mylohyoid and anterior belly of digastric; no secretomotor role.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frey’s syndrome results from aberrant regeneration of auriculotemporal nerve fibres that originally carried secretomotor supply to the parotid gland.

 

Parasympathetic pathway to the parotid gland :-

 

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 8

choices.text: A patient with true unilateral deafness hears sound only in the affected ear when both ears are stimulated
A malingerer will deny hearing any sound when the stimulus is stronger in the "deaf" ear and weaker in the normal ear
The test is used to confirm bilateral conductive hearing loss using tuning forks of different frequencies
A positive Stenger test confirms the diagnosis of sensorineural hearing loss in both ears

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the principle and interpretation of the Stenger test in a patient suspected of feigning unilateral hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A malingerer will deny hearing any sound when the stimulus is stronger in the "deaf" ear and weaker in the normal ear

 

Malingerer denies hearing when louder sound is in feigned deaf ear – Correct

 

Stenger test is a behavioral test used to detect non-organic or feigned unilateral hearing loss. It works on the Stenger principle:

 

When two tones of the same frequency but different intensities are presented simultaneously to both ears, the patient only perceives the louder tone.

 

How the test works:

 

  • Start by presenting equal-frequency sounds (via tuning forks or audiometer) to both ears.
  • Then move the sound closer to the side of the claimed deafness (i.e., make the sound louder in the "deaf" ear).
  • If the patient is truly deaf, they will continue to hear the tone in the normal ear.
  • If the patient is malingering, the louder sound in the "deaf" ear suppresses the softer one in the normal ear (per the Stenger principle), but the patient claims not to hear anything at all, revealing the deception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A patient with true unilateral deafness hears sound only in the affected ear when both ears are stimulated: Incorrect. A truly deaf ear won’t perceive sound; patient hears via normal ear.

 

Option C. The test is used to confirm bilateral conductive hearing loss using tuning forks of different frequencies: Stenger test is not diagnostic for bilateral conductive hearing loss.

 

Option D. A positive Stenger test confirms the diagnosis of sensorineural hearing loss in both ears: The test does not confirm SNHL in both ears; it's used for unilateral malingering.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Stenger test is used to detect unilateral malingering; if a patient denies hearing when a louder tone is presented to the "deaf" ear, it indicates feigned hearing loss (positive Stenger test).

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 22

choices.text: ASOM
Glomus Jugulare
Acoustic Neuroma
Otosclerosis

questions.text: A 45yr old female presented with gradual onset progressive hearing loss in the right ear associated with pulsatile tinnitus. The tympanic membrane appeared reddish. TFT showed Rinne was negative on the right side, positive on the left and Weber lateralised to the right. Tinnitus temporarily ceased with carotid pressure and auscultation over mastoid revealed an audible bruit. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glomus Jugulare

 

Option B. Glomus Jugulare: This is a vascular tumor of the middle ear. The patient's symptoms of gradual hearing loss, pulsatile tinnitus, a reddish tympanic membrane, temporary cessation of tinnitus with carotid pressure (aquino sign), and an audible bruit over the mastoid are classic for a glomus tumor. The negative Rinne test on the affected side and Weber's test lateralizing to the affected side indicate conductive hearing loss, which is consistent with a middle ear pathology like glomus jugulare.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. ASOM (Acute Suppurative Otitis Media): This condition typically presents with rapid onset ear pain, fever, and hearing loss. The presentation of pulsatile tinnitus, a reddish tympanic membrane, and a bruit over the mastoid are not characteristic of ASOM.

 

Option C. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma): This is a benign tumor of the cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear nerve). It typically presents with gradual hearing loss and tinnitus but does not produce a reddish tympanic membrane or an audible bruit. Also, acoustic neuroma usually causes sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive hearing loss.

 

Option D. Otosclerosis: Here, conductive hearing loss with intact tympanic membrane is noted but tinnitus is seen in only few people. And tinnitus, if present, is not pulsatile. Aquino sign is not seen here. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomus jugulare in patients presenting with pulsatile tinnitus, conductive hearing loss (as indicated by negative Rinne and lateralization of Weber to the affected side), a reddish tympanic membrane, and an audible bruit over the mastoid.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 109

choices.text: It helps differentiate cochlear from vestibular dysfunction
It is useful to localize lesions within the vestibular nerve versus end organ
The test is performed with the patient seated and eyes open
Normally, the patient sways away from the side of anodal stimulation

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the galvanic test is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is useful to localize lesions within the vestibular nerve versus end organ

 

  • This is the only vestibular test that helps in differentiating end organ (labyrinthine) lesions from vestibular nerve lesions by observing the postural sway in response to electrical stimulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It helps differentiate cochlear from vestibular dysfunction: Incorrect. The galvanic test is specific for the vestibular system and helps differentiate lesions of the vestibular nerve from those of the end organ (labyrinth). It does not assess cochlear function.

 

Option C. The test is performed with the patient seated and eyes open: Incorrect. The test is done with the patient standing, eyes closed, and arms outstretched to best assess postural sway and eliminate visual compensation.

 

Option D. Normally, the patient sways away from the side of anodal stimulation: Incorrect. Normally, the patient sways toward the side of the anodal current, due to altered vestibular input.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The galvanic test is a vestibular assessment that helps differentiate end organ (labyrinthine) lesions from vestibular nerve lesions by evaluating postural sway in response to anodal stimulation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 44

choices.text: Distraction test is reliable only after 12 months of age when the child develops speech
It uses pure tone audiometry to assess hearing thresholds in infants
It is used around 6–7 months of age when the child begins to localize sound
Only high-frequency sounds are used, such as 8 kHz rattles or whistles

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding distraction techniques used in pediatric hearing assessment is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is used around 6–7 months of age when the child begins to localize sound

 

  • At 6–7 months, a child typically develops the ability to turn their head toward sound, making this the ideal age for distraction testing. The examiner observes whether the child responds to a sound presented from behind or the side.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Distraction test is reliable only after 12 months of age when the child develops speech: Incorrect. Distraction techniques are specifically used around 6–7 months of age when the child starts localizing sound by turning the head, not after 12 months.

 

Option B. It uses pure tone audiometry to assess hearing thresholds in infants: Incorrect. Distraction testing is a behavioral method, not based on pure tones or thresholds. It relies on the child's response to various sound stimuli, not standard audiometric procedures.

 

Option D. Only high-frequency sounds are used, such as 8 kHz rattles or whistles: Incorrect. A range of sounds is used in distraction testing: high-frequency rattles (8 kHz), low-frequency hums, whispered "S" sounds, xylophones, warbled tones, and narrow band noise (500–4000 Hz).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Distraction testing is performed at 6–7 months of age to assess hearing by observing the child’s head-turning response to various sound stimuli presented out of sight.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 118

choices.text: A tone of 1000 Hz is presented at 20 dB above threshold for 60 seconds to assess cochlear pathology
A decay of more than 25 dB suggests a cochlear lesion
A tone of 4000 Hz is presented at 5 dB above threshold, and intensity is increased until the patient can hear it continuously for 60 seconds
The test is primarily used to assess the presence of middle ear pathology

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Threshold Tone Decay Test is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A tone of 4000 Hz is presented at 5 dB above threshold, and intensity is increased until the patient can hear it continuously for 60 seconds

 

  • This accurately describes the procedure of the Threshold Tone Decay Test, which is used to assess nerve fatigue and detect retrocochlear lesions. The tone is increased by 5 dB increments if the patient cannot hear it continuously for 60 seconds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A tone of 1000 Hz is presented at 20 dB above threshold for 60 seconds to assess cochlear pathology: Incorrect. The Threshold Tone Decay Test typically uses a 4000 Hz tone, not 1000 Hz, and it is initially presented at 5 dB above the hearing threshold, not 20 dB.

 

Option B. A decay of more than 25 dB suggests a cochlear lesion: Incorrect. A tone decay greater than 25 dB is diagnostic of a retrocochlear lesion (e.g., vestibular schwannoma), not cochlear pathology.

 

Option D. The test is primarily used to assess the presence of middle ear pathology: Incorrect. Middle ear pathology (e.g., otitis media) typically affects conductive hearing. This test is specifically used to detect retrocochlear (nerve) pathology, not middle ear disease.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Threshold Tone Decay Test detects retrocochlear lesions by measuring how much above threshold a 4000 Hz tone must be presented for the patient to hear it continuously for 60 seconds.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 26

choices.text: The central vestibular system includes the utricle, saccule, and semicircular ducts
The peripheral vestibular system is responsible for integrating impulses with other sensory systems
The central vestibular system includes vestibular nuclei and their connections within the CNS
The peripheral vestibular system includes the cochlea and auditory nerve

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the division of the vestibular system?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The central vestibular system includes vestibular nuclei and their connections within the CNS

 

  • The central vestibular system includes:
    • Vestibular nuclei (superior, medial, lateral, descending)
    • Fibre tracts such as the medial longitudinal bundle, vestibulospinal tract, and vestibulocerebellar connections
  • These coordinate reflexes and maintain body balance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The central vestibular system includes the utricle, saccule, and semicircular ducts: Incorrect. These structures are part of the peripheral vestibular system, not central. They are components of the membranous labyrinth that detect motion and orientation.

 

Option B. The peripheral vestibular system is responsible for integrating impulses with other sensory systems: Incorrect. The integration of vestibular information with visual, proprioceptive, and cerebellar input is the role of the central vestibular system, not peripheral.

 

Option D. The peripheral vestibular system includes the cochlea and auditory nerve: Incorrect. The cochlea and auditory nerve are part of the auditory system, not the vestibular system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The central vestibular system consists of vestibular nuclei and fibre tracts in the CNS, which integrate vestibular impulses to maintain body balance.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 17

choices.text: Sound waves reach both oval and round windows simultaneously to enhance perilymph vibration
Ossicular chain delivers sound preferentially to the round window for cochlear stimulation
Phase differential ensures compression at the oval window coincides with compression at the round window
Phase differential prevents cancellation of waves and ensures perilymph movement by offsetting compression and rarefaction

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly explains the importance of phase differential between the oval and round windows in the auditory system?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phase differential prevents cancellation of waves and ensures perilymph movement by offsetting compression and rarefaction

 

  • The phase differential between the oval and round windows—achieved via the ossicular chain, tympanic membrane, and air cushion around the round window—ensures that when compression hits the oval window, the round window bulges outward (rarefaction). This creates the necessary fluid movement in the cochlea for sound transduction and contributes about 4 dB to hearing efficiency when the tympanic membrane is intact.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sound waves reach both oval and round windows simultaneously to enhance perilymph vibration: Incorrect. If sound waves reach both windows simultaneously, the compressions and rarefactions would cancel each other out, leading to no effective movement of perilymph, and hence no hearing.

 

Option B. Ossicular chain delivers sound preferentially to the round window for cochlear stimulation: Incorrect. The ossicular chain transmits sound to the oval window, not the round window. The round window acts as a pressure release point.

 

Option C. Phase differential ensures compression at the oval window coincides with compression at the round window: Incorrect. Compression at the oval window is paired with rarefaction at the round window, creating fluid displacement inside the cochlea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase differential between the oval and round windows ensures alternate compression and rarefaction, preventing cancellation of waves and enabling perilymph movement for effective hearing.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 13.

choices.text: Visual input is the only component responsible for body balance in static posture
The vestibular system acts independently and is unaffected by somatosensory inputs
Body equilibrium is maintained by a push-pull system between bilateral vestibular inputs, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal
Loss of equilibrium is only seen during rapid movement, not in static imbalance

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the physiological basis for body equilibrium?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Body equilibrium is maintained by a push-pull system between bilateral vestibular inputs, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal

 

  • The body maintains equilibrium using a push-pull mechanism between bilateral vestibular systems. If one side becomes hyperactive or hypoactive, balance is disturbed. Reflexes like the:
    • Vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) stabilize gaze
    • Vestibulocervical reflex controls head position
    • Vestibulospinal reflex maintains trunk and limb posture
      Together, they ensure dynamic correction of posture and gaze.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Visual input is the only component responsible for body balance in static posture: Incorrect. Balance is a multisensory function, involving vestibular, visual, and somatosensory systems. Relying on vision alone is insufficient and does not explain conditions like vestibular ataxia.

 

Option B. The vestibular system acts independently and is unaffected by somatosensory inputs: Incorrect. The vestibular system integrates input from visual and somatosensory systems, especially during head movement or positional changes. It does not act in isolation.

 

Option D. Loss of equilibrium is only seen during rapid movement, not in static imbalance: Incorrect. A static imbalance due to vestibular dysfunction (e.g. unilateral vestibulopathy) can cause vertigo and ataxia even at rest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Equilibrium is maintained by a bilateral vestibular push-pull system integrated with visual and somatosensory input, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal responses.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 18

choices.text: SISI score is typically high in retrocochlear lesions like vestibular schwannoma
The test uses a continuous tone presented at threshold level with 5 dB increments
A SISI score between 70–100% is highly suggestive of cochlear pathology
Conductive hearing loss usually shows a SISI score above 70%

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Short Increment Sensitivity Index (SISI) test is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A SISI score between 70–100% is highly suggestive of cochlear pathology

 

  • Patients with cochlear hearing loss (e.g., Ménière’s disease, presbycusis) have increased sensitivity to small intensity changes, resulting in SISI scores of 70–100%, which is diagnostic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SISI score is typically high in retrocochlear lesions like vestibular schwannoma: Incorrect. Retrocochlear (nerve) lesions typically produce low SISI scores (0–20%) because these patients have poor sensitivity to small intensity changes.

 

Option B. The test uses a continuous tone presented at threshold level with 5 dB increments: Incorrect. In the SISI test, a continuous pure tone is presented 20 dB above threshold, and every 5 seconds a 1 dB increment (blip) is introduced — not 5 dB.

 

Option D. Conductive hearing loss usually shows a SISI score above 70%: Incorrect. In conductive hearing loss, SISI scores are usually <15%, as sound conduction is impaired but cochlear function remains intact.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A SISI score of 70–100% is indicative of cochlear pathology, helping differentiate it from retrocochlear and conductive causes of hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 26

choices.text: AIED typically presents with sudden, unilateral conductive hearing loss
Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for all patients diagnosed with AIED
Presence of anti-heat shock protein 70 (anti-Hsp70) antibodies may correlate with steroid responsiveness
Progression is defined as a threshold shift of 5 dB at any frequency on follow-up audiograms

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Autoimmune Inner Ear Disease (AIED) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presence of anti-heat shock protein 70 (anti-Hsp70) antibodies may correlate with steroid responsiveness

 

  • The Western blot assay for anti-Hsp70 antibodies is not specific but correlates with active disease and response to steroids, making it a useful supportive diagnostic marker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AIED typically presents with sudden, unilateral conductive hearing loss: Incorrect. AIED causes progressive, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, not sudden or conductive loss. Vestibular symptoms like vertigo may also be present.

 

Option B. Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for all patients diagnosed with AIED: Incorrect. The first-line treatment is prednisolone (1 mg/kg/day). Methotrexate is reserved for steroid non-responders or those who cannot tolerate steroids.

 

Option D. Progression is defined as a threshold shift of 5 dB at any frequency on follow-up audiograms: Incorrect. According to Moscicki's criteria, progression is defined as a ≥15 dB shift at one frequency or ≥10 dB at two or more consecutive frequencies, or a significant drop in speech discrimination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presence of anti-Hsp70 antibodies in autoimmune inner ear disease may correlate with active disease and steroid responsiveness, aiding in diagnosis and treatment planning.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 36

choices.text: Immediate onset of nystagmus, direction changing, non-fatiguable
Nystagmus with no vertigo and variable direction in each head position
Nystagmus with 2–20 second latency, fixed direction toward the undermost ear, and fatiguable
Nystagmus lasting over 1 minute, present in straight head-hanging position only

questions.text: Which of the following findings during a Hallpike manoeuvre is most suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) due to a peripheral cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nystagmus with 2–20 second latency, fixed direction toward the undermost ear, and fatiguable

 

  • These are hallmark features of BPPV, a peripheral vestibular disorder. The latency, brief duration, fixed direction, and fatiguability of nystagmus strongly support a peripheral origin, especially involving the posterior semicircular canal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate onset of nystagmus, direction changing, non-fatiguable: Incorrect. These features are characteristic of central positional vertigo, often due to cerebellar or brainstem lesions (e.g., IVth ventricle tumors, MS).

 

Option B. Nystagmus with no vertigo and variable direction in each head position: Incorrect. This pattern is again consistent with a central cause, where nystagmus occurs without associated vertigo and changes direction with head position.

 

Option D. Nystagmus lasting over 1 minute, present in straight head-hanging position only: Incorrect.  Nystagmus of long duration (>1 min) is not typical of BPPV and may point toward a central cause. Also, BPPV is diagnosed by testing multiple positions, not just straight head-hanging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BPPV is indicated by nystagmus with a latency of 2–20 seconds, fixed direction toward the undermost ear, and fatiguability on repeated Hallpike manoeuvre testing.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 42

choices.text: Adiadochokinesia and abnormal finger–nose test
Dysmetria and rebound phenomenon
Truncal ataxia and wide-based gait
Hemiplegia with spasticity and positive Babinski sign

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most consistent with midline cerebellar dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Truncal ataxia and wide-based gait

 

  • These are classic features of midline cerebellar dysfunction, often affecting the vermis. Such patients have difficulty maintaining upright posture, fall in any direction, and have impaired balance while walking or turning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adiadochokinesia and abnormal finger–nose test: Incorrect. These are signs of hemispheric cerebellar dysfunction, not midline. They indicate problems with coordination of limbs.

 

Option B. Dysmetria and rebound phenomenon:  Incorrect. Like Option A, these are also features of cerebellar hemisphere lesions, affecting voluntary limb control and force regulation.

 

Option D. Hemiplegia with spasticity and positive Babinski sign: Incorrect. These signs point to upper motor neuron lesions, especially involving the corticospinal tract, and are not cerebellar in origin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Midline cerebellar dysfunction typically presents with truncal ataxia, wide-based gait, falls in any direction, and difficulty turning while walking.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 42

choices.text: All frequencies stimulate the entire length of the basilar membrane uniformly
Shearing between basilar and tectorial membranes distorts hair cells, initiating cochlear microphonics
Low-frequency sounds stimulate the basal turn of the cochlea, while high frequencies reach the apex
The primary auditory neurons are multipolar and located in the cochlear nuclei

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding cochlear function and auditory transduction is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shearing between basilar and tectorial membranes distorts hair cells, initiating cochlear microphonics

 

  • Movement of the stapes footplate sets cochlear fluids into motion. This moves the basilar membrane, causing shearing between the basilar and tectorial membranes. This deforms the hair cells, leading to generation of receptor potentials (cochlear microphonics) and the initiation of nerve impulses.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All frequencies stimulate the entire length of the basilar membrane uniformly: Incorrect. According to von Békésy’s travelling wave theory, each sound frequency causes maximum displacement at a specific point along the basilar membrane:

 

  • High-frequency sounds → Basal turn
  • Low-frequency sounds → Apical turn

 

 

Option C. Low-frequency sounds stimulate the basal turn of the cochlea, while high frequencies reach the apex: Incorrect. It's the opposite:

 

  • High-frequency sounds → Base of cochlea (stiff, narrow part)
  • Low-frequency sounds → Apex of cochlea (wider, more compliant)

 

Option D. The primary auditory neurons are multipolar and located in the cochlear nuclei: Incorrect. Primary auditory neurons are bipolar, and their cell bodies are located in the spiral ganglion, not the cochlear nuclei. Their axons form the cochlear nerve.

 

 

Here is the reframed version of the paragraph with clearer and more natural phrasing, while retaining all the scientific details:

 

From Sound to Neural Signal:

 

Option A. Anatomy of the Ear: Sound waves enter through the pinna, pass along the ear canal, and cause the eardrum to vibrate. These vibrations are transmitted by the ossicles to the oval window, which in turn initiates fluid movement within the cochlea. This fluid movement generates a frequency-specific response based on the tonotopic organization, where each sound frequency resonates at a specific location along the cochlea.

 

Option B. Cochlear Structure: The cochlea consists of three fluid-filled compartments: scala tympani (ST), scala vestibuli (SV), and scala media (SM), which spiral around the central bony core called the modiolus (M). Inside the modiolus lies Rosenthal’s canal (RC), housing the cell bodies (somata) of auditory nerve fibers. These fibers serve as communication lines between the sensory hair cells of the organ of Corti (marked with a star) and the auditory processing centers of the brain.

 

Option C. 3D Visualization: A three-dimensional representation shows 30 colored auditory nerve fibers originating from different cochlear regions—basal (black), middle (green), and apical (red)—spiraling alongside the scala tympani. A 12-channel cochlear implant (light blue) with electrode contacts (gray circles) is shown inserted into the scala tympani, as modeled in our simulations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shearing between the basilar and tectorial membranes distorts hair cells, generating cochlear microphonics and initiating auditory transduction based on frequency-specific displacement along the basilar membrane.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 13

choices.text: VRA is best suited for children above 3 years of age
VRA involves conditioning the child to turn toward sound, reinforced by visual stimuli like flashing lights or animated toys
VRA uses only bone conduction testing as headphones are not well tolerated by infants
VRA cannot determine hearing thresholds using standard audiometric techniques

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Visual Reinforcement Audiometry (VRA) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) VRA involves conditioning the child to turn toward sound, reinforced by visual stimuli like flashing lights or animated toys

 

  • VRA is a conditioning technique where the child is trained to turn their head in response to an auditory stimulus, and this behavior is reinforced by flashing lights or animated toys, helping to determine hearing thresholds.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VRA is best suited for children above 3 years of age: Incorrect. VRA is ideally suited for children in the developmental age of 6 months to 2 years, not above 3 years, where behavioral conditioning to auditory cues is more effective.

 

Option C. VRA uses only bone conduction testing as headphones are not well tolerated by infants: Incorrect. VRA typically uses headphones or insert earphones, not exclusively bone conduction. Insert earphones are especially preferred in infants as they are lightweight and better tolerated.

 

Option D. VRA cannot determine hearing thresholds using standard audiometric techniques: Incorrect. One of the main uses of VRA is to determine hearing thresholds using standard audiometric techniques, making it highly valuable in early pediatric hearing assessment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visual Reinforcement Audiometry (VRA) is used in children aged 6 months to 2 years to assess hearing by conditioning head-turning responses to sound, reinforced with visual stimuli.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 118

choices.text: It is preferred over water caloric testing in patients with intact tympanic membranes
It uses warm air to stimulate the cochlear portion of the inner ear
It is contraindicated in tympanic membrane perforation
It is a qualitative vestibular test using cooled air through a Dundas Grant tube

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the cold-air caloric test is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is a qualitative vestibular test using cooled air through a Dundas Grant tube

 

  • The cold-air caloric test is a rough qualitative test of vestibular function, utilizing cooled air (typically via ethyl chloride cooling) delivered through a Dundas Grant tube in cases where water irrigation is contraindicated, such as TM perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is preferred over water caloric testing in patients with intact tympanic membranes: Incorrect. The cold-air caloric test is used specifically when the tympanic membrane is perforated, as water irrigation is contraindicated in such cases. In intact TMs, water caloric testing is more accurate.

 

Option B. It uses warm air to stimulate the cochlear portion of the inner ear: Incorrect. The test uses cold air, not warm air, and it assesses vestibular function, not cochlear. The Dundas Grant tube helps deliver cooled air to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canal.

 

Option C. It is contraindicated in tympanic membrane perforation: Incorrect. In fact, this test is performed because there is a TM perforation — it's a safe alternative to avoid water entering the middle ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cold-air caloric test is a qualitative vestibular test used when the tympanic membrane is perforated, utilizing cooled air delivered through a Dundas Grant tube.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 43

choices.text: Pinna
External auditory meatus
Cochlea
Middle ear

questions.text: Based on the development timeline of ear structures, which of the following completes its development latest during fetal life?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Middle ear

 

 

From the chart:

  • Pinna:
    • Begins: 6th week
    • Completes: 20th week
  • Meatus (External auditory canal):
    • Begins: 8th week
    • Completes: 28th week
  • Middle ear:
    • Begins: 3rd week
    • Completes: 30th week 
  • Vestibular labyrinth:
    • Begins: 3rd week
    • Completes: 20th week
  • Cochlea:
    • Begins: 3rd week
    • Completes: 20th week

 

Hence, the middle ear is the last among these structures to complete development, finishing at the 30th week of gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the ear structures, the middle ear completes its development last—by the 30th week of gestation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 12

choices.text: Spiral ganglion is located in the modiolus of the cochlea and contains multipolar neurons
The auditory cortex is located in the inferior frontal gyrus (Brodmann area 4)
Each ear is represented only in the contralateral cerebral hemisphere
The axons of bipolar neurons in the spiral ganglion form the cochlear nerve and terminate in the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the auditory neural pathway is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The axons of bipolar neurons in the spiral ganglion form the cochlear nerve and terminate in the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei

 

  • Hair cells synapse with dendrites of bipolar neurons in the spiral ganglion. Their axons form the cochlear division of CN VIII, which terminates in the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei of the medulla.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spiral ganglion is located in the modiolus of the cochlea and contains multipolar neurons: Incorrect. The spiral ganglion lies in Rosenthal’s canal, which runs along the osseous spiral lamina (not in the modiolus), and contains bipolar (not multipolar) neurons.

 

 

Option B. The auditory cortex is located in the inferior frontal gyrus (Brodmann area 4): Incorrect. The auditory cortex is located in the superior temporal gyrus, corresponding to Brodmann’s area 41, not area 4 (which is the primary motor cortex in the precentral gyrus).

 

 

Option C. Each ear is represented only in the contralateral cerebral hemisphere: Incorrect. Due to multiple decussations in the central auditory pathway, each ear is represented bilaterally in both cerebral hemispheres.

 

Mnemonic:

 

E. COLI-MA

 

  • E – Eighth nerve
  • C – Cochlear nuclei
  • O – Olivary complex
  • L – Lateral lemniscus
  • I – Inferior colliculus
  • M – Medial geniculate body
  • A – Auditory cortex

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cochlear nerve arises from bipolar neurons in the spiral ganglion and projects to the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei, with the auditory pathway ascending bilaterally through E. COLI-MA to the auditory cortex in Brodmann area 41.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 13.

choices.text: Clearance of middle ear secretions via mucociliary action
Protection of middle ear from nasopharyngeal pressure and secretions
Equalization of pressure across tympanic membrane
Continuous drainage of perilymph from the inner ear

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of the Eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continuous drainage of perilymph from the inner ear

 

The Eustachian tube plays a crucial role in the physiology of the middle ear, not the inner ear. It performs three key functions:

 

1. Ventilation (Pressure Equalization)

 

  • Maintains equal air pressure on both sides of the tympanic membrane
  • Opens during swallowing, yawning, sneezing
  • Poor function leads to negative/positive middle ear pressure, impairing hearing
  • Less efficient in supine position, infants, or during sleep

 

2. Protection

 

  • Prevents entry of:
    • Excessive nasopharyngeal sound pressure
    • Reflux of secretions from nasopharynx
  • This protective function is impaired in:
    • Patulous ET
    • Short, wide tubes in infants
    • TM perforation
    • Forceful nose blowing, nasal obstruction, or adenoids

 

3. Clearance

 

  • Lined by ciliated columnar epithelium (especially anterior middle ear + ET)
  • Cilia beat toward nasopharynx
  • Helps in clearing secretions/debris from middle ear
  • Aided by active opening and closing of the ET

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clearance of middle ear secretions via mucociliary action: True function.  Clearance via mucociliary action

 

Option B. Protection of middle ear from nasopharyngeal pressure and secretions: True function. Protection from nasopharyngeal pressure/secretions

 

Option C. Equalization of pressure across tympanic membrane: True function: Pressure equalization for optimal tympanic membrane vibration

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Eustachian tube ventilates the middle ear, protects it from nasopharyngeal secretions and pressure, and clears secretions via mucociliary action.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 58

choices.text: Canal wall up procedure has a lower rate of residual disease and does not require a second-look surgery
Canal wall down procedure provides a normal meatal appearance and allows unrestricted swimming
Canal wall up procedure preserves a normal meatus and is better suited for patients requiring hearing aids
Canal wall down procedure requires second-look surgery to rule out cholesteatoma recurrence

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the comparison between canal wall up and canal wall down mastoidectomy procedures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Canal wall up procedure preserves a normal meatus and is better suited for patients requiring hearing aids

 

  • Canal wall up procedure preserves the normal appearance of the external canal (meatus) and makes wearing hearing aids easier, which is important for auditory rehabilitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Canal wall up procedure has a lower rate of residual disease and does not require a second-look surgery: Incorrect. Canal wall up procedure actually has a higher rate of recurrent or residual cholesteatoma and hence typically requires a second-look surgery after 6 months.

 

Option B. Canal wall down procedure provides a normal meatal appearance and allows unrestricted swimming: Incorrect. Canal wall down procedure results in a widely open meatus, but swimming is generally restricted due to risk of mastoid cavity infections.

 

Option D. Canal wall down procedure requires second-look surgery to rule out cholesteatoma recurrence: Incorrect. Second-look surgery is not required in canal wall down procedures due to low recurrence rates.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Canal wall up mastoidectomy maintains normal meatal anatomy and allows easier use of hearing aids, but has a higher risk of residual disease, while canal wall down is safer for disease clearance but has limitations in swimming and hearing aid fitting.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 73
questions.video_explanation_heading: POST OPERATIVE APPEARANCE OF CANAL WALL DOWN MASTOIDECTOMY

choices.text: Prescribe antihistamines and decongestants
Evaluate the nasopharynx to rule out carcinoma
Insert a grommet after myringotomy
Perform tympanoplasty

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with unilateral hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals a dull tympanic membrane and fluid behind it, suggestive of otitis media with effusion (OME). What should be the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Evaluate the nasopharynx to rule out carcinoma

 

  • In elderly patients, unilateral OME should raise suspicion for nasopharyngeal carcinoma, especially involving the Fossa of Rosenmüller, which can obstruct the Eustachian tube. Nasopharyngoscopy and biopsy are crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prescribe antihistamines and decongestants: Incorrect. While antihistamines and decongestants are used in children or allergic cases, in an elderly patient with unilateral OME, such treatment without further investigation may delay diagnosis of serious pathology.

 

Option C. Insert a grommet after myringotomy: Incorrect. Grommet insertion may relieve symptoms, but doing it before ruling out malignancy may delay appropriate cancer diagnosis and treatment.

 

Option D. Perform tympanoplasty: Incorrect. Tympanoplasty is a reconstructive procedure used in cases of tympanic membrane perforation or chronic otitis media, not in OME.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unilateral otitis media with effusion in an elderly patient should prompt evaluation for nasopharyngeal carcinoma, especially in the Fossa of Rosenmüller.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 251
questions.video_explanation_heading: LEFT UNILATERAL OME, RIGHT EAR NORMAL, LEFT NPC, RIGHT NASOPHARYNX NORMAL

choices.text: It uses a 15° cephalocaudal beam and does not show the attic or antrum clearly
It is primarily used to assess nasopharyngeal tumors extending into the Eustachian tube
It shows the key area of the mastoid including antrum and upper attic, using a 30° cephalocaudal beam
The sagittal plane is perpendicular to the film and the internal and external auditory canals are separated

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes Schuller’s view in radiological imaging of the temporal bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It shows the key area of the mastoid including antrum and upper attic, using a 30° cephalocaudal beam

 

  • Schuller’s view is similar to Law’s but uses a 30° cephalocaudal beam, and clearly shows the key mastoid area—antrum, attic, sinodural angle, and helps assess pneumatization, cholesteatoma, and fractures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It uses a 15° cephalocaudal beam and does not show the attic or antrum clearly: This is a description of Law’s view, not Schuller’s. Law’s view uses a 15° beam and does not visualize the key area well.

 

Option B. It is primarily used to assess nasopharyngeal tumors extending into the Eustachian tube: Incorrect. Schuller’s view is for temporal bone and mastoid imaging, not for soft tissue structures of the nasopharynx.

 

Option D. The sagittal plane is perpendicular to the film and the internal and external auditory canals are separated: Incorrect. As with Law’s view, in Schuller’s view, the sagittal plane is parallel to the film, and the EAC is superimposed on the IAC, not separated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schuller’s view uses a 30° cephalocaudal beam with the sagittal plane parallel to the film and is useful for visualizing the mastoid antrum, attic, and sinodural angle, making it ideal for assessing mastoiditis, cholesteatoma, and petrous fractures.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 433

choices.text: Stage of tubal occlusion
Stage of presuppuration
Stage of suppuration
Stage of resolution

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with complaints of fever, severe earache, vomiting, and reduced hearing. Otoscopic examination reveals a bulging, red tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks, and a yellow spot is visible. What stage of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM) is this child most likely in?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage of suppuration

 

Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM) evolves in five classic stages:

 

1. Stage of Tubal Occlusion:

 

  • Cause: Eustachian tube blockage due to URTI
  • TM: Retraction, horizontal malleus handle, dull cone of light
  • Symptoms: Mild earache, conductive hearing loss
  • No fever, usually no visible fluid

 

2. Stage of Presuppuration:

 

  • TM: Red, congested, "cart-wheel" appearance
  • Symptoms: Marked earache, fever, restlessness, tinnitus
  • Exudate begins to form in middle ear

 

3. Stage of Suppuration (Answer):

 

  • TM: Bulging, red, yellow spot (site of imminent rupture), loss of landmarks
  • Symptoms: Severe earache, high fever (102–103°F), vomiting, possibly convulsions
  • Pus starts to collect in middle ear & mastoid

 

4. Stage of Resolution:

 

  • TM ruptures → pus drains
  • Relief of pain, fever subsides
  • Perforation often in anteroinferior quadrant, discharge becomes mucopurulent

 

5. Stage of Complication:

 

  • If untreated or virulent organism:
    • Mastoiditis, labyrinthitis, facial palsy, meningitis, brain abscess, etc.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage of tubal occlusion: Only mild retraction and deafness, not fever or bulging TM

 

Option B. Stage of presuppuration: TM is red but not bulging; no yellow spot

 

Option D. Stage of resolution: TM has ruptured, symptoms start improving

 

Educational Objective:

 

The suppurative stage of ASOM is marked by bulging tympanic membrane, yellow spot, severe earache, and high fever, indicating accumulation of pus in the middle ear.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 62

choices.text: Ruedi’s theory
Wittmaack’s theory
Sade’s theory
Habermann’s theory

questions.text: Which of the following theories of cholesteatoma origin involves retraction pocket formation due to invagination of tympanic membrane epithelium?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wittmaack’s theory

 

Cholesteatoma is defined as the presence of keratinizing squamous epithelium within the middle ear cleft, where it is not normally present. Several theories have been proposed to explain its origin, particularly how this epithelium gains access to the middle ear.

 

Key Theories of Cholesteatoma Formation:

 

  1. Wittmaack’s Theory (Invagination Theory)
    • Describes formation of retraction pockets from attic or posterosuperior pars tensa
    • Outer epithelium invaginates and lays down keratin
    • Most widely accepted in acquired cholesteatoma
  2. Ruedi’s Theory (Basal Cell Hyperplasia)
    • Infection stimulates basal cell proliferation
    • Forms keratinizing squamous epithelium
  3. Habermann’s Theory (Epithelial Invasion)
    • Squamous epithelium migrates from EAC into middle ear via pre-existing marginal perforation
  4. Sade’s Theory (Metaplasia Theory)
    • Respiratory epithelium of middle ear undergoes metaplasia to squamous epithelium due to chronic infection
  5. Congenital Theory
    • Epithelial rests remain in the middle ear from embryonic development and give rise to cholesteatoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ruedi’s theory:  Basal cell proliferation theory, not retraction

 

Option C. Sade’s theory: Involves metaplasia, not invagination

 

Option D. Habermann’s theory: Involves epithelial migration through a perforation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wittmaack’s theory explains cholesteatoma formation due to retraction pocket of tympanic membrane epithelium invaginating into the middle ear.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 67

choices.text: Lempert’s curette – used for removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery
Freer’s elevator – used to elevate tympanomeatal flap
Myringotome – used for incision in tympanic membrane
Mollison’s retractor – used for soft tissue retraction in postaural mastoidectomy

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and select the correct statement regarding its use:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lempert’s curette – used for removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery

 

  • The instrument shown is Lempert’s curette (also called Lempert’s scoop). It has a rounded scoop-like end and is commonly used in mastoidectomy to remove bony septa between air cells and clear out granulation tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Freer’s elevator: Freer’s elevator is a double-ended blunt instrument used to elevate flaps, especially during septoplasty, not for bone or granulation removal.

 

 

Option C. Myringotome: A myringotome is a fine angled knife used to make a precise incision in the tympanic membrane, not to remove bone or granulations.

 

 

Option D. Mollison’s retractor: This is a self-retaining retractor used for soft tissue retraction in postaural approaches, not a curette.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lempert’s curette is used in mastoidectomy to remove bony septa and granulation tissue from the mastoid air cells.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 452

choices.text: Diffuse serous labyrinthitis
Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis
Meniere’s disease
Vestibular neuronitis

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with chronic ear infection develops sudden severe vertigo, vomiting, and complete hearing loss in one ear. Examination reveals spontaneous nystagmus with the quick component directed to the opposite ear. He appears toxic. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis

 

  • Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis is characterized by severe vestibular failure, spontaneous nystagmus with quick component to the healthy side (due to destruction of affected labyrinth), total hearing loss, and systemic toxicity. It is irreversible and may lead to intracranial complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse serous labyrinthitis: Incorrect. Serous labyrinthitis is non-purulent, usually reversible, and presents with milder symptoms. In this case, the severe vertigo, complete hearing loss, and toxic appearance suggest a more advanced stage.

 

Option C. Meniere’s disease: Incorrect. Meniere’s disease presents with fluctuating SNHL, tinnitus, episodic vertigo, and ear fullness—not with complete hearing loss and toxicity.

 

Option D. Vestibular neuronitis: Incorrect. Vestibular neuronitis causes vertigo without hearing loss and typically occurs in otherwise healthy individuals. It lacks the systemic toxicity seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis presents with severe vertigo, vomiting, complete hearing loss, and spontaneous nystagmus toward the healthy side, and requires urgent antibiotic therapy and possible surgical intervention.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 81

choices.text: Pyogenic meningitis
Otitic hydrocephalus
Subdural abscess
Tuberculous meningitis

questions.text: A 12-year-old child with a recent history of chronic otitis media presents with severe headache, diplopia, and episodes of blurred vision. Fundoscopy shows papilloedema. CSF examination reveals an opening pressure of 310 mm H₂O but normal cell counts, proteins, sugars, and sterile cultures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Otitic hydrocephalus

 

  • Otitic hydrocephalus is a condition of raised intracranial pressure with normal CSF findings, typically seen in children or adolescents with acute or chronic middle ear infections. It is associated with lateral sinus thrombosis that impedes venous drainage and may involve the superior sagittal sinus, affecting CSF absorption. Key features include:
    • Severe headache, vomiting
    • Diplopia (VI nerve palsy)
    • Papilloedema
    • CSF opening pressure >300 mm H₂O with normal composition

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyogenic meningitis: Incorrect because pyogenic meningitis shows raised CSF pressure along with high protein, low glucose, and neutrophilic pleocytosis. In this case, CSF is biochemically and cytologically normal, making meningitis unlikely.

 

Option C. Subdural abscess: Subdural abscess usually presents with focal neurological deficits, altered mental status, and signs of meningeal irritation, and CSF is not typically normal. Imaging helps confirm it.

 

Option D. Tuberculous meningitis: This typically shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, high protein, and low sugar in CSF. Here, the CSF is sterile and normal in contents, ruling it out.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otitic hydrocephalus presents with raised intracranial pressure and normal CSF findings, typically due to lateral sinus thrombosis following middle ear infection.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 85

choices.text: Freer’s elevator – used for raising tympanomeatal flap in tympanoplasty
MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker – used in mastoid surgery to explore air cells and remove septa
Lempert’s curette – used to remove nasal polyps in outpatient setting
Mollison’s retractor – used to retract skin flaps in neck dissection

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and select the correct statement regarding its use:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker – used in mastoid surgery to explore air cells and remove septa

 

  • The instrument shown is MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker, which is double-ended:
    • One end is used to seek and explore mastoid air cells,
    • The other is a curette used to remove bony septa and granulation tissue during mastoidectomy.
      It is a standard tool in mastoid surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Freer’s elevator:  This instrument has a flat and rounded end used to elevate mucoperichondrial flaps in septoplasty, not for curettage or air cell exploration.

 

 

Option C. Lempert’s curette: While also used in mastoid surgery, it has a spoon-like scoop, not this dual-ended structure.

 

 

Option D. Mollison’s retractor: This is a self-retaining retractor used to retract soft tissues in mastoid or neck surgeries, not to curette bone or explore cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker is a dual-ended instrument used in mastoid surgery to explore air cells and remove bony septa or granulations.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 452

choices.text: Suppuration – Excruciating Earache, Deafness and Bulging TM with pus, CHL
PreSuppuration – Throbbing Pain, Deafness and Cartwheel TM, CHL
Resolution – Ear Discharge and patient starts to feel Better, Perforation in Antero-Inferior Quadrant, CHL improves
All above options are correct

questions.text: Which of the following signs and symptoms are not true with the respective stage of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All above options are correct

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Suppuration Stage: During this stage of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM), there is typically excruciating earache, hearing loss (deafness), and a bulging tympanic membrane (TM) with visible pus. The hearing loss in this case is usually conductive hearing loss (CHL) due to the middle ear being filled with pus, which hinders the movement of the TM and the ossicles.

 

Option B. Presuppuration Stage: This stage precedes the suppuration and is characterized by throbbing ear pain and deafness. The TM often appears red and inflamed, sometimes described as a "cartwheel" appearance, and there is usually CHL due to the Eustachian tube dysfunction and the accumulation of fluid in the middle ear.

 

Option C. Resolution Stage: In the resolution stage, the patient often starts to feel better, and there might be ear discharge due to the perforation of the TM. The perforation is typically seen in the antero-inferior quadrant. With the release of pus through the perforation, the pressure in the middle ear decreases, leading to an improvement in CHL.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The progression of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media through different stages - tubal occlusion (retracted TM, mild ear pain & block), presuppuration (throbbing pain, deafness, cartwheel TM appearance, CHL), suppuration (excruciating earache, deafness, bulging TM with pus, CHL), and resolution (ear discharge, improvement in symptoms, perforation in the antero-inferior quadrant of TM, improvement in CHL). 

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 62, 63

choices.text: Acute Suppurative Otitis Media
Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media
Serous Otitis Media
Adhesive Otitis Media

questions.text: Identify?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serous Otitis Media

 

Option C. Also known as Otitis Media with Effusion, SOM would show a dull, amber-colored tympanic membrane due to the presence of serous fluid in the middle ear. There may be an air-fluid level or bubbles seen behind the tympanic membrane.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. In ASOM, the tympanic membrane typically appears red and bulging due to the presence of pus in the middle ear. It is associated with acute infection and symptoms such as ear pain, fever, and possibly otorrhea if perforation occurs. The image does not show these features.

 

Option B. CSOM is characterized by persistent ear discharge through a perforated tympanic membrane and a long-standing infection. The tympanic membrane may show granulation tissue or a visible perforation. The image does not show signs of active discharge or perforation.

Option D. This condition is characterized by a retracted tympanic membrane that has become thin and atrophic, causing it to adhere to the ossicles and/or inner ear structures. The image shows a retracted tympanic membrane with a parchment-like appearance and scarring, which are hallmarks of adhesive otitis media.

Educational Objective:

 

In Serous otitis media, a dull, amber-colored tympanic membrane is present due to the presence of serous fluid in the middle ear. There may be an air-fluid level or bubbles seen behind the tympanic membrane.

 

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 64

choices.text: Myringotomy
Myringotomy + Grommet Insertion
Grommet Insertion only
Adenoidectomy + Grommet Insertion

questions.text: A 6-yr-old child presents with recurrent URTI with mouth breathing and failure to grow with high arched palate and impaired hearing. His tympanogram showed b type curve. He should be managed by
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adenoidectomy + Grommet Insertion

 

Option D. This combined approach addresses both the adenoid hypertrophy, which is likely contributing to Eustachian tube dysfunction, recurrent URTIs, and mouth breathing, as well as the middle ear effusion causing the hearing impairment. Adenoidectomy can reduce nasal obstruction and improve Eustachian tube function, while grommet insertion provides a route for the middle ear to ventilate and drain, thus helping with the impaired hearing.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Myringotomy involves making an incision in the tympanic membrane to relieve pressure and drain fluid. While it can provide temporary relief, it does not address the underlying problem of Eustachian tube dysfunction, which is likely in this case given the recurrent upper respiratory tract infections (URTI) and mouth breathing.

 

Option B. Myringotomy with grommet insertion would address the middle ear effusion as evidenced by the type B tympanogram (indicative of fluid in the middle ear), but it may not be enough if there is significant adenoid hypertrophy contributing to Eustachian tube dysfunction and recurrent URTIs.

 

Option C. Grommet insertion alone would address the middle ear effusion and associated hearing impairment, but it would not treat the probable adenoid hypertrophy that is causing mouth breathing and recurrent URTIs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with recurrent URTIs, mouth breathing, and a type B tympanogram, adenoid hypertrophy is a likely contributing factor. Thus, management should include both adenoidectomy to address the adenoid hypertrophy and grommet insertion to resolve the middle ear effusion and associated hearing loss.

 

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 65

choices.text: Meniere's disease
Acoustic neuroma
Perilymph fistula
Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV)

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset vertigo, nausea, and hearing loss in his right ear following a deep scuba diving session earlier in the day. He denies any recent upper respiratory infections, otalgia, or discharge from the ear. On examination, you note horizontal nystagmus and a negative Rinne test on the affected side. The tympanic membrane is intact without signs of inflammation or effusion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perilymph fistula

 

Option C.

 

In this scenario, the sudden onset of symptoms following a pressure-altering event (scuba diving), combined with hearing loss and vertigo without any signs of middle ear infection or inflammation, points towards a perilymph fistula. Diagnosis can be challenging and often relies on clinical presentation and history, as physical exam findings can be subtle or nonspecific.

 

Perilymph fistula is a condition where there is an abnormal communication between the perilymph-filled space within the inner ear and the air-filled middle ear or mastoid. This can lead to the leakage of perilymph fluid, causing symptoms such as sudden onset vertigo, hearing loss, and sometimes tinnitus, especially after events that change ear pressure like diving, flying, or heavy lifting. The presence of vertigo and hearing loss after a pressure event (like scuba diving) with an intact tympanic membrane strongly suggests a perilymph fistula.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Meniere's disease typically presents with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. These episodes can last from 20 minutes to several hours, not typically associated with diving or immediate onset after a pressure change.

 

Option B. Acoustic neuroma is a benign tumor of the cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear nerve) that usually presents with progressive unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes balance disturbances. Its onset is gradual, not sudden after an event like diving.

 

Option D. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by brief episodes of vertigo related to head position changes. It is caused by dislodged otoliths moving into one of the semicircular canals, leading to inappropriate stimulation of the vestibular system. There's typically no hearing loss associated with BPPV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perilymph fistula is a cause of sudden onset vertigo and hearing loss following a pressure-altering event, distinguished by the absence of tympanic membrane inflammation or effusion, and negative findings for other causes of vertigo and hearing loss.

choices.text: Absence of nystagmus with both warm and cold water irrigation
Direction-changing nystagmus with warm water irrigation in the left ear and cold water irrigation in the right ear
Nystagmus beating toward the irrigated ear with warm water and away from the irrigated ear with cold water
Stronger nystagmus with cold water irrigation than with warm water irrigation in both ears

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of vertigo, particularly when she turns her head quickly. To assess her vestibular function, the physician decides to perform a Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test. Which of the following outcomes of this test is considered normal?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nystagmus beating toward the irrigated ear with warm water and away from the irrigated ear with cold water

 

Option C.

 

This is the correct answer and represents the normal response in the Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test. Warm water irrigation causes endolymph in the semicircular canals to rise, simulating head movement towards the irrigated side, leading to nystagmus beating toward the irrigated ear. Conversely, cold water irrigation causes the endolymph to fall, simulating head movement away from the irrigated side, leading to nystagmus beating away from the irrigated ear.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Absence of nystagmus with both warm and cold water irrigation: This outcome is abnormal. The normal response to caloric testing involves the induction of nystagmus, which is a rapid, involuntary movement of the eyes. The absence of nystagmus may indicate a vestibular dysfunction.

 

Option B. Direction-changing nystagmus with warm water irrigation in the left ear and cold water irrigation in the right ear: While nystagmus direction can change based on the ear being irrigated and the temperature of the water, this option does not accurately describe the expected directional pattern for a normal response.

 

Option D. Stronger nystagmus with cold water irrigation than with warm water irrigation in both ears: The strength of nystagmus is not the primary indicator of a normal response in the caloric test. The direction of the nystagmus in relation to the ear being irrigated and the temperature of the water is more relevant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test evaluates vestibular function by inducing nystagmus through the irrigation of the external auditory canal with warm and cold water. The normal response is nystagmus that beats toward the irrigated ear with warm water and away with cold water.

choices.text: The microphone converts sound into electrical signals, the amplifier magnifies them, and the receiver converts them back to sound
The amplifier picks up sound and sends it directly to the tympanic membrane
The receiver captures sound and converts it into electrical signals for processing
The microphone sends electrical signals directly to the cochlea through a bone conduction pathway

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the role of components in a conventional hearing aid?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The microphone converts sound into electrical signals, the amplifier magnifies them, and the receiver converts them back to sound

 

  • This is the basic working principle of a conventional hearing aid:
    • The microphone picks up environmental sound and converts it into an electrical signal.
    • The amplifier boosts this signal to a suitable level.
    • The receiver then converts the amplified electrical signal back into sound, which is delivered to the ear.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. The amplifier picks up sound and sends it directly to the tympanic membrane: Incorrect. The microphone, not the amplifier, picks up sound. The amplifier deals with electrical impulses, not sound waves.

 

Option C. The receiver captures sound and converts it into electrical signals for processing: Incorrect. This is the role of the microphone, not the receiver. The receiver works at the final stage to deliver the processed sound.

 

Option D. The microphone sends electrical signals directly to the cochlea through abone conduction pathway: Incorrect. This describes bone conduction hearing aids, not conventional air-conduction hearing aids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a conventional hearing aid, the microphone converts sound into electrical signals, the amplifier boosts them, and the receiver converts them back to sound delivered to the ear.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 121

choices.text: Longer duration of deafness with no prior use of hearing aids
Younger age at implantation, especially in prelingually deaf children
Prelingual adults with no auditory experience before implantation
Use of single-channel implants with auditory training

questions.text: Which of the following factors is most strongly associated with better clinical outcomes following cochlear implantation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Younger age at implantation, especially in prelingually deaf children

 

  • Younger age, especially around 12 months, correlates with better auditory and speech development due to greater neural plasticity. Early stimulation improves language acquisition and long-term outcomes.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Longer duration of deafness with no prior use of hearing aids: Incorrect. Longer auditory deprivation and lack of prior auditory stimulation are associated with poorer outcomes, especially in prelingual adults.

 

Option C. Prelingual adults with no auditory experience before implantation: Incorrect. These individuals derive limited benefit, mostly sound awareness, with little improvement in speech comprehension or language development.

 

Option D. Use of single-channel implants with auditory training: Incorrect. Multichannel implants are now standard and perform significantly better than single-channel devices. Single-channel devices are obsolete.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Younger age at implantation, particularly in prelingually deaf children, is a strong predictor of successful outcomes with cochlear implants due to higher neural plasticity.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 125

choices.text: BAHA transmits sound through the external auditory canal and ossicular chain
BAHA is contraindicated in conductive or mixed hearing loss
The sound processor of BAHA is implanted at the time of initial surgery
BAHA transmits sound vibrations directly to the cochlea via bone, bypassing the external and middle ear

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Bone-Anchored Hearing Aids (BAHA) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) BAHA transmits sound vibrations directly to the cochlea via bone, bypassing the external and middle ear

 

  • BAHA uses a titanium fixture surgically implanted into the skull. Once osseointegrated, a sound processor attached to the external abutment sends vibrations through the skull directly to the cochlea, effectively bypassing the external and middle ear.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BAHA transmits sound through the external auditory canal and ossicular chain: Incorrect. Unlike conventional air-conduction aids, BAHA bypasses both the external auditory canal and the ossicular chain, delivering vibrations directly to the cochlea through bone conduction.

 

Option B. BAHA is contraindicated in conductive or mixed hearing loss: Incorrect. BAHA is primarily indicated for conductive, mixed, and single-sided deafness, especially in patients who cannot use traditional hearing aids.

 

Option C. The sound processor of BAHA is implanted at the time of initial surgery
Incorrect. The sound processor is attached only after osseointegration of the titanium implant, which typically takes 2–6 months after surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BAHA transmits sound vibrations directly to the cochlea via bone conduction, bypassing the external auditory canal and middle ear.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 122
