choices.text: Hearing aids are recommended for individuals with hearing loss that cannot be corrected by medical or surgical means
Sensorineural hearing loss is a contraindication for hearing aids due to inevitable sound distortion
Conductive hearing loss is not treated with hearing aids under any circumstance
Hearing aids are delayed in deaf children until after 5 years of age to assess speech development

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the indications for hearing aid use is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hearing aids are recommended for individuals with hearing loss that cannot be corrected by medical or surgical means

 

  • This is the fundamental indication for hearing aids — to amplify sound in patients with hearing impairment not amenable to medical or surgical treatment, including many with sensorineural or conductive hearing loss.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Sensorineural hearing loss is a contraindication for hearing aids due to inevitable sound distortion: Incorrect. While some patients with sensorineural loss may experience sound distortion or recruitment, many can benefit from hearing aids if properly fitted.

 

Option C. Conductive hearing loss is not treated with hearing aids under any circumstance: Incorrect. While surgery is preferred, hearing aids are prescribed when surgery is refused, not feasible, or has failed.

 

Option D. Hearing aids are delayed in deaf children until after 5 years of age to assess speech development: Incorrect. Early fitting of hearing aids is essential in deaf children to promote speech and language development, ideally as early as possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hearing aids are indicated for individuals with hearing loss that cannot be corrected by medical or surgical treatment.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 121

choices.text: Blepharospasm usually affects only one eye and is most commonly caused by acoustic neuroma
Botulinum toxin is ineffective in hemifacial spasm but useful in treating exposure keratitis
Hemifacial spasm can be caused by a vascular loop compressing the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle
Selective nerve section is contraindicated in the treatment of essential hemifacial spasm and blepharospasm

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding hyperkinetic disorders of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemifacial spasm can be caused by a vascular loop compressing the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle

 

  • Many cases of hemifacial spasm are due to neurovascular compression at the cerebellopontine angle, often by a vascular loop. Treatment includes microvascular decompression, which has a high success rate.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Blepharospasm usually affects only one eye and is most commonly caused by acoustic neuroma: Incorrect. Blepharospasm is a bilateral involuntary spasm of orbicularis oculi muscles and is not typically caused by acoustic neuroma. Its origin is believed to lie in the basal ganglia.

 

Option B. Botulinum toxin is ineffective in hemifacial spasm but useful in treating exposure keratitis: Incorrect. Botulinum toxin is effective in both hemifacial spasm and blepharospasm. It works by blocking acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction. It is not used for exposure keratitis.

 

Option D. Selective nerve section is contraindicated in the treatment of essential hemifacial spasm and blepharospasm: Incorrect. Selective section of facial nerve branches may be considered in essential hemifacial spasm or blepharospasm if other treatments fail. It is not contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemifacial spasm may be caused by a vascular loop compressing the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle and is treatable by microvascular decompression or botulinum toxin.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 103–104.

choices.text: Most commonly caused by parietal blows and associated with conductive hearing loss
Often associated with bleeding from the ear and injury to ossicles
Involve sensorineural hearing loss and immediate facial paralysis in most cases
Characterized by CSF otorrhea that is usually mixed with blood

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding transverse fractures of the temporal bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Involve sensorineural hearing loss and immediate facial paralysis in most cases

 

  • Transverse fractures are less common (20%) and usually result from occipital blows. They run across the petrous part of the temporal bone and often damage the labyrinth or CN VIII, leading to sensorineural hearing loss. They also frequently cause immediate facial paralysis (50%), due to injury in the meatal or labyrinthine segment proximal to the geniculate ganglion.

 

 

(A) Longitudinal fracture follows the long axis of the petrous part of the temporal bone. It typically originates from the squamous part of the temporal bone, extends through the roof of the external auditory canal and middle ear, and continues toward the petrous apex, ending near the foramen lacerum.

 

(B) Transverse fracture runs perpendicular to the petrous axis. It usually begins at the foramen magnum, traverses the occipital bone and jugular fossa, passes through the petrous pyramid, and ends in the middle cranial fossa. In its course, it may pass medial to, lateral to, or directly through the labyrinth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Most commonly caused by parietal blows and associated with conductive hearing loss: Incorrect. This describes longitudinal fractures, which are more common (80%), result from parietal blows, and cause conductive hearing loss.

 

Option B. Often associated with bleeding from the ear and injury to ossicles: Incorrect. Again, this is seen in longitudinal fractures, due to involvement of the tympanic membrane and ossicles.

 

Option D. Characterized by CSF otorrhea that is usually mixed with blood: Incorrect. CSF otorrhea mixed with blood is more typical of longitudinal fractures, not transverse ones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transverse temporal bone fractures typically cause sensorineural hearing loss and immediate facial paralysis due to injury to the labyrinth or proximal facial nerve.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 100–101.

choices.text: Objective tinnitus is most commonly psychogenic and occurs without any identifiable physical source
Venous hum and vascular lesions like glomus tumors are typical causes of subjective tinnitus
Clicking tinnitus due to palatal myoclonus is an example of subjective tinnitus that occurs during swallowing
Abnormally patent eustachian tube and palatal myoclonus can cause objective tinnitus synchronized with respiration or muscle contractions

questions.text: Which of the following statements about causes of tinnitus is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abnormally patent eustachian tube and palatal myoclonus can cause objective tinnitus synchronized with respiration or muscle contractions

 

  • These conditions cause objective tinnitus. A patulous (patent) eustachian tube causes respiration-synchronous tinnitus, while palatal myoclonus produces a clicking sound due to rhythmic contractions of the soft palate.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Objective tinnitus is most commonly psychogenic and occurs without any identifiable physical source: Incorrect. Psychogenic tinnitus is a form of subjective tinnitus, and objective tinnitus typically has a real, physical cause such as vascular or muscular abnormalities.

 

Option B. Venous hum and vascular lesions like glomus tumors are typical causes of subjective tinnitus: Incorrect. These are classic causes of objective tinnitus, often synchronous with the pulse, and may be temporarily relieved by pressure on vessels.

 

Option C. Clicking tinnitus due to palatal myoclonus is an example of subjective tinnitus that occurs during swallowing: Incorrect. Palatal myoclonus is a cause of objective tinnitus, as the sound is produced by actual muscular contractions and can sometimes be heard by an examiner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective tinnitus may result from physical sources like palatal myoclonus or a patulous eustachian tube, producing sounds synchronized with muscle activity or respiration.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 130

choices.text: Hypoglossal-facial anastomosis restores facial movement without any impact on tongue function
End-to-end anastomosis is preferred when the nerve gap is large and requires tension to bridge
Cable grafting is used when the gap between severed nerve ends is too large for direct anastomosis
Decompression involves rerouting the entire facial nerve to relieve mechanical pressure

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding surgical management of facial nerve injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cable grafting is used when the gap between severed nerve ends is too large for direct anastomosis

 

  • In cases where the gap is too wide for safe end-to-end approximation, nerve grafts (such as from greater auricular, sural, or lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh) are used to bridge the defect.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Hypoglossal-facial anastomosis restores facial movement without any impact on tongue function: Incorrect. While this procedure improves facial tone and some movement, it does lead to ipsilateral tongue atrophy, causing temporary difficulties in chewing and articulation.

 

Option B. End-to-end anastomosis is preferred when the nerve gap is large and requires tension to bridge: Incorrect. End-to-end anastomosis is only done when the gap is minimal, and no tension is present between the ends. Tension can compromise healing and function.

 

Option D. Decompression involves rerouting the entire facial nerve to relieve mechanical pressure: Incorrect. Decompression involves uncapping the bony canal and slitting the nerve sheath to relieve pressure from edema or hematoma. It does not involve rerouting the nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cable grafting is indicated when the gap between severed facial nerve ends is too large to allow tension-free end-to-end anastomosis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 105.

choices.text: The facial nerve lies lateral to the short process of incus at the level of aditus
The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus
The tympanic segment of the facial nerve starts at the posterior end of the digastric ridge
The geniculate ganglion is located posterior to the processus cochleariformis

questions.text: During middle ear surgery, which of the following correctly describes a key surgical landmark for identifying the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus

 

  • The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus. This is a key landmark for the mastoid or vertical segment of the facial nerve during surgery.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. The facial nerve lies lateral to the short process of incus at the level of aditus: Incorrect. The facial nerve lies medial to the short process of incus, not lateral, at the level of the aditus ad antrum.

 

Option C. The tympanic segment of the facial nerve starts at the posterior end of the digastric ridge: Incorrect. The tympanic segment begins at the level of the processus cochleariformis, not near the digastric ridge. The digastric ridge is related to the exit point of the nerve from the mastoid.

 

Option D. The geniculate ganglion is located posterior to the processus cochleariformis: Incorrect. The geniculate ganglion lies anterior to the processus cochleariformis and is the site where the nerve takes its first turn (first genu).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus in its vertical (mastoid) segment, serving as a key landmark in middle ear surgery.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 96.

choices.text: It is the longest segment of the facial nerve and lies within the internal acoustic meatus
It extends from the geniculate ganglion to the stylomastoid foramen
It is the shortest and narrowest segment, making it vulnerable to compression-related paralysis
It lies below the oval window and lateral semicircular canal

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is the shortest and narrowest segment, making it vulnerable to compression-related paralysis

 

  • The labyrinthine segment is just 4 mm long and has the narrowest bony canal (0.61–0.68 mm), making it the most vulnerable segment to inflammation or edema, which can cause facial nerve paralysis.

 

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It is the longest segment of the facial nerve and lies within the internal acoustic meatus: Incorrect. The meatal segment lies within the internal acoustic meatus and measures 8–10 mm, but the labyrinthine segment is shorter (about 4 mm).

 

Option B. It extends from the geniculate ganglion to the stylomastoid foramen
Incorrect. This describes the combined tympanic and mastoid segments, not the labyrinthine segment.

 

Option D. It lies below the oval window and lateral semicircular canal
Incorrect. This describes the tympanic (horizontal) segment, not the labyrinthine segment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve is the shortest and narrowest portion, making it highly susceptible to compression-induced facial paralysis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 90

choices.text: CROS aids use a bone conduction oscillator placed on the mastoid of the deaf ear
CROS aids are primarily used in bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss
CROS aids deliver sound from the better ear to the poorer ear for improved clarity
CROS aids transmit sound from the deaf ear to the better ear to improve sound awareness on the deaf side

questions.text: Which of the following statements about CROS (Contralateral Routing of Signals) hearing aids is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CROS aids transmit sound from the deaf ear to the better ear to improve sound awareness on the deaf side

 

  • CROS hearing aids are used in single-sided deafness, where they route sound from the non-hearing side to the hearing side, improving awareness and localization. However, bone-anchored hearing aids are now preferred alternatives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CROS aids use a bone conduction oscillator placed on the mastoid of the deaf ear: Incorrect. This describes bone conduction hearing aids or bone-anchored hearing aids (BAHA), not CROS. CROS aids use a microphone on the deaf side and receiver on the normal side.

 

Option B. CROS aids are primarily used in bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss: Incorrect. CROS aids are specifically designed for unilateral profound hearing loss, not bilateral.

 

Option C. CROS aids deliver sound from the better ear to the poorer ear for improved clarity: Incorrect. It is the reverse — CROS aids pick up sound from the deaf ear side and send it to the better ear to help with sound localization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CROS hearing aids route sound from the deaf ear to the better ear, helping with sound localization in cases of single-sided deafness.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 122

choices.text: Biopsy is the investigation of choice to confirm glomus tympanicum
CT scan shows salt and pepper appearance due to tumor vascularity
Most glomus tumors are functional and secrete catecholamines
The tumor most likely arises from the promontory and receives blood from the ascending pharyngeal artery

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss. Otoscopy reveals a reddish mass behind the intact tympanic membrane that blanches on applying pressure with Siegel’s speculum. Which of the following is true regarding her likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The tumor most likely arises from the promontory and receives blood from the ascending pharyngeal artery

 

  • Correct. This describes glomus tympanicum, fitting the clinical picture given.

 

The patient has classical features of a glomus tympanicum (a type of glomus tumor), the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear, especially in females.

 

Key features include:

 

  • Pulsatile tinnitus, conductive hearing loss
  • Reddish mass behind intact TM → suggests Rising Sun Sign
  • Blanching of mass with pressure via Siegel’s speculum → Brown's Sign
  • Aquino sign: blanching with ipsilateral carotid compression
  • Highly vascular, so biopsy is contraindicated
  • CT scan shows Phelps sign (not salt & pepper)
  • MRI shows salt & pepper appearance
  • Glomus tympanicum arises from the promontory
  • Feeding artery: inferior tympanic branch of ascending pharyngeal artery

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biopsy is the investigation of choice to confirm glomus tympanicum

 

  • Incorrect. Never do biopsy due to risk of uncontrolled bleeding in vascular lesions.

 

Option B. CT scan shows salt and pepper appearance due to tumor vascularity

 

  • Incorrect. Salt and pepper appearance is seen on MRI, not CT.
  • CT shows Phelps sign: obliteration of caroticojugular spine.

 

Option C. Most glomus tumors are functional and secrete catecholamines

 

  • Incorrect. Only ~10% are functional, per the rule of 10.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomus tympanicum is a highly vascular middle ear tumor arising from the promontory, often in females, presenting with pulsatile tinnitus, and is fed by the inferior tympanic branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery; biopsy is contraindicated.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 109

choices.text: It is a branch of glossopharyngeal nerve that enters the middle ear through the Eustachian tube
It runs lateral to the tympanic membrane between the incus and the stapes
It carries secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland and taste fibres from posterior one-third of tongue
It carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and passes between handle of malleus and long process of incus

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the chorda tympani nerve is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and passes between handle of malleus and long process of incus

 

Taste from anterior 2/3 and path between handle of malleus and long process of incus: Correct

 

Chorda tympani:

  • Is a branch of the facial nerve (CN VII)
  • Enters middle ear through the posterior canaliculus
  • Runs on the medial surface of the tympanic membrane
  • Lies between the handle of malleus and long process of incus, above the tendon of tensor tympani
  • Carries:
    • Taste fibres from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue
    • Preganglionic parasympathetic fibres to submandibular and sublingual glands via submandibular ganglion

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a branch of glossopharyngeal nerve that enters the middle ear through the Eustachian tube: Incorrect. Chorda tympani is from facial nerve, and does not enter via Eustachian tube

 

Option B. It runs lateral to the tympanic membrane between the incus and the stapes: Incorrect. Runs on the medial surface of tympanic membrane, and between malleus and incus, not incus and stapes

 

Option C. It carries secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland and taste fibres from posterior one-third of tongue: Incorrect. Parotid is supplied by glossopharyngeal; posterior 1/3 taste is via CN IX, not chorda tympani

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chorda tympani is a branch of facial nerve that carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and secretomotor fibres to submandibular/sublingual glands, running between the handle of malleus and long process of incus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 8
